info:
First Year University Studies in
Information and Computer Science
In all Brunel University London information and computer science degrees, students develop a range of skills
valued by employers such as communication, teamwork, analysis and project management. Each programme
has a strong contemporary feel and relates information and computer management theory and concepts to
the practical issues facing managers in the 21st Century. Successful completion of the degree can lead to career
opportunities in business, project management, computing, social networking and business analysis.
In Stage 2/ level 1 of the programme you will take the following core modules, five in the first semester and four in the second.
In Semester one you will study: In Semester two you will study:
• Interactive Learning Skills and Communication • Group Project cont.
• Group Project Semester1 • Introductory Programming cont.
• Introductory Programming Semester 1 • Data and Information cont.
• Data and Information Semester 1 • Information Systems & Organisations
• Information Systems & Organisations Semester 1 • Logic and Computation cont.
• Logic and Computation Semester 1

Group Project
This Group Project module seeks to integrate skills covered Information Systems & Organisations

significant degree of programming and technical engagement. dynamic, and emergent behaviour of information systems (IS)

Introductory Programming Logic and Computation
The aim of the module is primarily to develop problem-solving This module aims to provide the students with knowledge
skills. Java programming is used as a vehicle to empower the and skills to model problems using mathematics and logic,

practice and some of the underlying principles shared by appropriate modelling methods and computational paradigms
all programming languages and those particular to object in order to achieve practical computational solutions.
oriented programming.
